qas.question: How many types of Guna exist in Hindu philosophy?
Which state of guna is that of compassion, positiveness, and goodness?
Which type of guna is concened with passion and activity?
What is the focus of the guna for negativeness and destruction?
What is the interpretation of classical  of Samkhya?
How many types of Sattva are there?
What do all life forms have in equal proportion?
The fact that Samkhya denies the existence of a soul makes it what?

plausible_answers.text: the character of someone or something

qas.question: What does Ishvara determine in a person's life?

context: Samkhya philosophy includes a theory of gunas (qualities, innate tendencies, psyche). Guna, it states, are of <a0_0><b5_0>three<b5_0/><a0_0/> types: <a1_0>Sattva<a1_0/> being good, compassionate, illuminating, positive, and constructive; <a2_0>Rajas<a2_0/> guna is one of activity, chaotic, passion, impulsive, potentially good or bad; and <a3_0>Tamas<a3_0/> being the quality of darkness, ignorance, destructive, lethargic, negative. Everything, all life forms and human beings, state Samkhya scholars, have these <b6_0>three gunas<b6_0/>, but in different proportions. The interplay of these gunas defines <b9_0>the character of someone or something<b9_0/>, of nature and determines the progress of life. Samkhya theorises a pluralism of souls (Jeevatmas) who possess consciousness, but <b7_0>denies the existence of Ishvara (God)<b7_0/>. Classical Samkhya is considered an <a4_0><b8_0>atheist / non-theistic<b8_0/><a4_0/> Hindu philosophy.
